numerics.hyperbolics
Class bessel

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--numerics.hyperbolics.bessel
public final class bessel
extends java.lang.Object

Overview
The Bessel class provides the function bessel_function that returns the modified bessel function of the first kind [ bessel(X,V) ] for real values X & V. All real combinations of V and X are valid except: (V fractional, X < 0) and (V < 0 AND Fractional, X=0). This function is a java port of the bessel function developed in C by the Risoe National Laboratory (RNL)- which in turn was a fortran port. The Bessel class requires the Gamma class which was also derived from RNL. The Java Bessel function was compared with the Mathematica 4.0 bessel function and provided excellent agreement. This function was provided by Peter Kirkegaard at peter.kirkegaard@risoe.dk.

Class verification and debugging technique. The bessel function was tested for a range of orders and arguments. The order 'v' was varied between -3 and 3 by 0.5 and the argument 'x' was varied between 0.001 and 19.5 by 0.5. These Java bessel function results for this range of values were compared to the Mathematica bessel function evaluations and were found to be nearly identical. The output from the functions are presented at the bottom of java source file.

ACTION AND REVISION LOG 

 Author        Date     Action
 --------------------------------------------------------------------------
 RISOE NL      09-01-95  RISOE Computer Laboratory Created C++ bessel function port
 Tony Held(TH) 01-19-00  Function received from RISOE (orginally called besine)
 TH            01-19-00  RISOE C bessel function evaluations were comporable to the Mathematica subroutines
 TH            08-09-00  Function ported to Java Class
 TH            08-12-00  Class commented and Java bessel function results compared favorably with Mathematica
Java Port Notes Given that the original code was in C++ a few minor changes had to be made to the bessel function 1. #include statements removed 2. long and short int types converted to long or int respectively 3. modf function changed from C++ version to my simplified java version 4. FRACV and ODDV changed to boolean type 5. exit statements changed to system.exit calls 6. math functions prefixed with Math. 7. casts from double to long were made explicit 8. printf statements replaced with System.out.println 9. goto replaced with a continue statement 10. AL, TWOA, and NEGV initialized because the compiler complained if they were not

ORIGINAL COMMENTS FROM THE RISOE LABORATORY C FILE 
 C ------------------------------ besine.c ------------------------------
 C ***********           RISOE NATIONAL LABORATORY            ***********
 C ***********       RISOE COMPUTER LIBRARY     OCT 1995      ***********
 C ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 C PURPOSE
 C     COMPUTES THE MODIFIED BESSEL FUNCTION  I  OF ORDER V AND WITH
 C     ARGUMENT X. ALL REAL COMBINATIONS OF V AND X ARE VALID EXCEPT:
 C     (V FRACTIONAL, X.LT.0)  AND  (V.LT.0 AND FRACTIONAL, X=0).
 C
 C METHOD
 C     THE PRESENT FUNCTION IS FROM A FORTRAN TRANSLATION WITH SOME MODIFICA-
 C     TIONS OF AN ALGOL CODE WRITTEN BY GAUTSCHI(1,2).
 C
 C DESCRIPTION OF ARGUMENTS                         (IN=INPUT,OUT=OUTPUT)
 C  X      IN   GIVEN ARGUMENT
 C  V      IN   GIVEN ORDER. A FRACTIONAL VALUE IS ALLOWED.
 C  JINT   IN   OPTION FOR EXPONENTIAL FACTOR ON THE RESULT, SEE BELOW.
 C  besine RESULTING RETURN VALUE (Y). IF JINT = 1 THEN SIMPLY  Y = I-SUB-V(X)
 C              IS RETURNED. IF JINT = 2, Y = I-SUB-V(X) * EXP(-ABS(X))
 C              IS RETURNED. THE LATTER OPTION IS USEFUL WHEN THERE IS A
 C              RISK FOR OVERFLOWS IN CASE OF LARGE X VALUES.
 C
 C REFERENCES
 C    (1) W.GAUTSCHI, COMPUTATIONAL ASPECTS OF THREE-TERM RECURRENCE
 C        RELATIONS. SIAM REVIEW 9(1967)24-82.
 C    (2) W.GAUTSCHI, ALGORITHM 236 BESSEL FUNCTIONS OF THE FIRST KIND.
 C        COMM. ACM 7(1964)479-480.
 C    (3) M.ABRAMOWITZ AND I.A.STEGUN, HANDBOOK OF MATHEMATICAL FUNCTIONS
 C        ,NBS APPL.MATH.SER.55, WASHINGTON (1964).

 C *********** E N D  O F  D E S C R I P T I O N  F I E L D *************

Version:
1.0 (October 2001)
Author:
Tony Held (Java Port), RISOE National Laboratory (Fortran + C Port)

Method Detail

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] argv)
main is only used to verify that the bessel function results are similar to standard mathematical routines such as Mathematica. The bessel.main method will output modified bessel function values for a range of values defined by 6 arguments. The 6 arguments will be converted from string to type double.
usage: java numerics.hyperbolics.bessel XLowerBound XUpperBound XIncrement VLowerBound VUpperBound VIncrement
example: java numerics.hyperbolics.bessel 0.001 19 0.5 -3 3 0.5
Parameters:
XLowerBound - Lower bound of X considered for the modified bessel function.
XUpperBound - Upper bound of X considered for the modified bessel function.
XIncrement - Increment between XLowerBound and XUpperBound considered for the modified bessel function.
VLowerBound - Lower bound of order V considered for the modified bessel function.
VUpperBound - Upper bound of order V considered for the modified bessel function.
VIncrement - Increment between VLowerBound and VUpperBound considered for the modified bessel function.

bessel_function

public static final double bessel_function(double X,
                                           double V,
                                           long JINT)
bessel_function calculates the modified bessel function of the first kind of real order V and real argument X. All real combinations of v and x are valid except: (V fractional, X<0) and (v<0 AND fractional, X=0).
Parameters:
X - a double value.
V - a double value representing the order of the modified bessel function.
JINT - a long exponential factor that is useful in preventing overflows for large X values.
JINT should always be 1 unless there is a very compelling reason to do otherwise.
The java port has never been tested for JINT values other than 1 - although there is no real reason why it should not work as designed by RNL.
If JINT = 1 then simply Y = I-SUB-V(X) is returned.
If JINT = 2, Y = I-SUB-V(X) * EXP(-ABS(X)) is returned.
Returns:
a double value which is a numerical estimation of the modified bessel function.
